topics.body:
"@SeraphimDawn":/dis/the-time-wasting-thread/post/557df9db63687272a4000321#post_557df9db63687272a4000321
[bq="SeraphimDawn"]"@uc9":/dis/the-time-wasting-thread/post/557df99e63687251f1002bb0#post_557df99e63687251f1002bb0
HOORAY!

That's why we aren't getting any word from them for quite some time.[/bq]
This is just my personal opinion, but the way I think space travel will happen in the long run is:
Over the next 200 years they will slowly work on terraforming mars; keep in mind the constantly deadly radiation so genetically engineering organisms to survive is going to take a lot of effort.  Cannabis may be able to survive that sort of environment off the bat, but you can't survive off eating weed all day.

2025-2040 will start mining operations of specific asteroids.  Some asteroids are rich with rare minerals and such that back home are expensive.

One theory as to why materials like gold, platinum and such are rare on earth is that they sink down and most of it is trapped in the earth's core.  Another theory is that the reason why the earth still has life is that not only do larger objects lose heat slower but that the earth's core is like a giant fission reactor.

If they find stuff like platinum on a asteroid then chances are the usa will shift drastically to a outer space minimum economy.  You'll probably see giant multi-corporation cooperative missions to mine asteroids.

The reason why I think this would be good is that such a industry would potentially be worth hundreds of trillions of dollars.

topics.body:
"@SeraphimDawn":/dis/the-time-wasting-thread/post/557dff7363687251b6003683#post_557dff7363687251b6003683
What kind of annoys me about terraforming is once I had a severe argument about the possibilities of terraforming mars, but the reason why I remember this argument is that during the debate I brought a bunch of scientific journo papers to the debate and I said "Earth's core is partially fueled by fission because of the pressure of it, but that doesn't mean that we can't terraform mars because extremophiles are bacteria and organisms that can survive that environment; it would just take hundreds of years to get the atmosphere breathable".  I got such utter shit for saying that the earth's core had fission going on even though it was scientifically backed and everything.

That's actually how I initially found out about the "feels before reals" crowd, cause I got in such shit over that cause my scientific evidence backing me got me into such utter deep shit that day.

Even if a planet's core is dead it's not impossible to terraform it, the ecosystem would have to rely on extremophiles to keep the planet alive.

Terraforming say Venus or such would take drastically more effort than mars though, cause you would have to dump a bunch of gases that cause cooling rather and then wait a couple hundred years for it to get cool enough for extremophiles then engineer them to give off both oxygen and cooling gas instead.


Tl:dr; to terraform mars just heat it up.  To terraform venus you would have to cool it then engineer extremophile bacteria to release greenhouse gases if it's too cold, but on the other hand release gases that cool the planet if it gets too hot but also eats those gases if the concentration is too high.

Tl:dr; terraforming mars is easy compared to other planets.
